חנניה-בן-תרדיון~(Rabbi) Haninah ben Teradion or Hananiah ben Teradion- was a teacher in the third Tannaitic generation (2nd century). He was a contemporary of Eleazar ben Perata I and of Halafta, together with whom he established certain ritualistic rules (Ta'anit ii. 5)- he was also one of the Ten Martyrs murdered by the Romans for ignoring the ban on teaching Torah

יהודה-אשלג~(Rav) Yehuda (Leib Ha-Levi) Ashlag (also known as the Baal Ha-Sulam) (1885 - 1954)- an orthodox rabbi and kabbalist born in Lodz (Congress Poland, Russian Empire) to a family of scholars connected to the Hasidic courts of Porisov and Belz
יהודה-בן-בבא~(Rabbi) Judah ben Baba- was a rabbi in the 2nd century who ordained a number of rabbis at a time when the Roman government forbade this ceremony- the penalty was execution for the ordainer and the new rabbis- the rabbis ordained by Rabbi Judah ben Baba include Judah ben Ilai. Rabbi Judah ben Baba was killed by Hadrian's soldiers at the age of seventy, and is known as one of the "Ten Martyrs"
יהודה-בן-יחזקאל~Judah ben Ezekiel (220–299)- also known as Rav Yehuda- was a Babylonian amora of the 2nd generation
יהודה-בר-אילעאי~(Rabbi) Judah (Yehuda) bar Ilai, also known as Rabbi Judah or Rabbi Judah ben Ilai- was a Tanna (a sage recorded in the Mishna), who lived in the 2nd Century. Of the many Rabbi Yehuda's in the Talmud he is the one referred to simply as Rabbi Yehuda
יהודה-המכבי~Judah Maccabee = "Judah the Hammer"- was a Kohen and a son of the Jewish priest Mattathias, and the leader the Maccabean revolt against the Seleucid Empire (167-160 BCE) and is acclaimed as one of the greatest warriors in Jewish history alongside Joshua, Gideon and David
יהודה-הנשיא~Rabbi Yehuda haNasi = "Rabbi Judah the Prince"- a key leader of the Jewish community of Judea toward the end of the 2nd century CE

יהודה-נשיאה-השלישי~Judah (IV or) Nesi'ah III- held the office of Nasi of the ancient Jewish Sanhedrin between 385 and 400 CE, following Gamaliel V. He was succeeded by Gamaliel VI, the last occupant of the office
יהודה-נשיאה-השני~Judah III, or Nesi'ah II- held the office of Nasi of the ancient Jewish Sanhedrin between 290 and 320 CE. He is a famous Jewish sage mentioned in the classical works of Judaism's oral law, who lived during the third and beginning of the fourth century CE.

יהודים~Jews
יהודית~Jewish, Jewess, Yiddish, or Hebrew (Bib.), also Judith = "Jewess" or "praised"- the daughter of Beeri the Hittite and wife of Esau
יהוה~Yahweh = "I am", or "the existing One"- the name of God given to Moses with the ten Comandments- the proper name of the one true God
יהוה-צבאות~The Lord Of Hosts
יהוהירה~Jehovah-jireh = "Jehovah sees"- symbolic name given by Abraham to Mount Moriah in commemoration of the Binding of Isaac
יהוהנסי~Jehovah-nissi = "Jehovah is my banner"- the name given by Moses to the altar which he built in commemoration of the discomfiture of the Amalekites
יהוהצדקנו~Ye-ho-vaw' tsid-kay'-noo = "Jehovah is our righteousness" a sacred name symbolically applied to Jerusalem and the Messiah;
יהוהשלום~Jehovah-shalom = "Jehovah is peace"- the name of a sacred altar built by Gideon in Ophrah
יהוהשמה~Jehovah-shammah = "Jehovah is there"- a symbolic name for Jerusalem
יהוזבד~Jehozabad = "Jehovah has endowed"- son of Shomer, a Moabitish woman, who murdered Joash, king of Judah, also a Benjamite, captain of 180,000 armed men, in the days of Jehoshaphat, also a Korhite Levite, 2nd son of Obededom, and one of the porters of the temple and of the storehouse there in the time of David
יהוחנן~Jehohanan = "Jehovah has graced"- a priest during the high priesthood of Joiakim who returned with Zerubbabel
יהוידע~Jehoiada = "Jehovah knows"- father of Benaiah, David's mighty warrior, also leader of the priests who joined David at Hebron, also high priest at the time of Athaliah's usurpation of the throne of Judah; hid Joash, the king's son, for six years and eventually replaced him on the throne of Judah, also second priest, or sagan, to Seraiah the high priest
יהויכין~Jehoiachin = "Jehovah establishes"- king of Judah, son of Jehoiakim, and the next to last king of Judah before the Babylonian captivity
יהויקים~Jehoiakim = "Jehovah raises up"- son of Josiah and the third from the last king of Judah, subject vassel of Nebuchadnezzar
יהויריב~Jehoiarib = "Jehovah contends"- A priest in Jerusalem, also the head of the 1st of the 24 courses of priests in David's time
יהוכל~Jehucal = "Jehovah is able"- a son of Shelemiah and a servant of king Zedekiah whom he sent to Jeremiah to entreat his prayers and advice
יהונדב~Jehonadab = "Jehovah is willing"- a son of Rechab, chief of the Rechabites, in the time of Jehu and Ahab, also a nephew of David
יהונתן~Jonathan or Jehonathan = "Jehovah has given"- a son of king Saul and a friend of David, also a son of the high priest Abiathar and the last descendant of Eli of whom we hear
יהוסף~Joseph = "Jehovah has added"- the eldest son of Jacob by Rachel
יהועדה~Jehoadah = "Jehovah has adorned"- a descendant of Saul through Jonathan
יהועדין~Jehoaddan = "Jehovah delights"- wife of king Joash and mother of king Amaziah of Judah
יהועדק~Jehozadak or Josedech = "Jehovah is righteous"- grandson of the high priest Hilkiah; son of the high priest Seraiah; and father of the high priest Joshua; he never attained the office of high priest himself because he was carried captive to Babylon by Nebuchadnezzar
יהוצדק~Jehozadak or Josedech = "Jehovah is righteous"- grandson of the high priest Hilkiah; son of the high priest Seraiah; and father of the high priest Joshua
יהורם~Jehoram or Joram = "Jehovah is exalted"- son of king Jehoshaphat of Judah and himself king of Judah for 8 years, also son of king Ahab of the northern kingdom of Israel and king of Israel himself for 12 years, also a priest in the reign of Jehoshaphat
יהושבע~Jehosheba = "Jehovah has sworn"- daughter of king Joram of Judah and wife of the high priest Jehoiada
יהושבעת~Jehoshabeath = "Jehovah is an oath"- daughter of king Joram of Judah and wife of the high priest Jehoiada
יהושוע~Joshua or Jehoshua = "Jehovah is salvation"- son of Nun of the tribe of Ephraim and successor to Moses as the leader of the children of Israel who led the conquest of Canaan, also a resident of Beth-shemesh on whose land the Ark of the Covenant came to a stop after the Philistines returned it, also son of Jehozadak and high priest after the restoration, also governor of Jerusalem under king Josiah who gave his name to a gate of the city of Jerusalem, also full spelling of Yeshua (Jesus)- hebrew name of the man belived to be the Missiah by many
יהושוע-בן-נון~Joshua the son of Nun- of the tribe of Ephraim and successor to Moses as the leader of the children of Israel (he led the conquest of Canaan)
יהושוע-בן-פרחיה~Joshua ben Perachya- was Nasi of the Sanhedrin in the latter half of the second century BC. He and his colleague Nittai of Arbela were the second of the five pairs (Zugot) of scholars who received and transmitted Jewish tradition (Avot i.6; Haggigah 16a)

יצחק-לוריא-בן-שלמה~(Rabbi) Isaac Luria ben Solomon- aka "The Ari", "Ari-Hakadosh", or "Arizal," meaning "The Lion,"- was a foremost rabbi and Jewish mystic in the community of Safed in the Galilee region of Ottoman Palestine, and his is considered the father of contemporary Kabbalah- he is also known for the interpretation of his teachings in Kabbalah known as Lurianic Kabbalah
יצחק-ניוטון~(Sir) Isaac Newton (4 January 1643 – 31 March 1727 [OS: 25 December 1642 – 20 March 1727])- was an English physicist, mathematician, astronomer, natural philosopher, alchemist, and theologian, and is considered by many scholars and members of the general public to be one of the most influential people in human history

משה-בן-נפתלי~Moses ben Naphtali- a rabbi and Masorete who flourished about 890-940, probably in Tiberias
משה-דיין~Moshe Dayan- was an Israeli military leader and politician. The fourth Chief of Staff of the Israel Defense Forces (1953–1958), he became a fighting symbol to the world of the new State of Israel- He went on to become Defense Minister and later Foreign Minister of Israel
משה-מנדלסון~Moses Mendelssohn (6 September 1729 – 4 January 1786)- was a German Jewish philosopher to whose ideas the Haskalah (the 'Jewish enlightenment' of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries) is indebted
משה-פיינשטיין~(Rabbi) Moshe Feinstein (March 3, 1895 – March 23, 1986)- was a Lithuanian Orthodox rabbi, scholar and posek (an authoritative adjudicator of questions related to Jewish law) who was world-renowned for his expertise in Halakha and was regarded by many as the de facto supreme halakhic authority for Orthodox Jewry of North America during his lifetime
משה-קורדובירו~Moses (ben Jacob) Cordovero (1522–1570)- was a leading Jewish mystic in 16th-century Safed, and is known by the acronym the Ramak

צ'אד~Chad- (officially known as the Republic of Chad)- is a landlocked country in central Africa- It is bordered by Libya to the north, Sudan to the east, the Central African Republic to the south, Cameroon and Nigeria to the southwest, and Niger to the west. Due to its distance from the sea and its largely desert climate, the country is sometimes referred to as the "Dead Heart of Africa"

רב-פפא~Rav Papa- was a Jewish Talmudist who lived in Babylonia- he was an Amora- a student of both Rava and Abaye and he led the Talmudical academy in Nehardea

רב-שרירא~Rav Sherira
רב-שרירא-גאון~Rav Sherira Gaon (910 CE. - 1010 CE.)- was the head of the yeshiva in Pumbeditha and one of the most prominent Geonim of his period (he wrote the Iggeret Rav Sherira Gaon = "[The] Epistle of Rav Sherira Gaon"- a comprehensive history of the composition of the Talmud)
רב-תאי~multicellular
רבא~(Aramaic)- great, or grand, also Rava, or Abba ben Joseph bar CHama- was a Jewish Talmudist who lived in Babylonia, known as an amora, born in 270- he is one of the most often-cited Rabbis in the Talmud
רבאות~tens of thousands

רבגוניות~multiplicity, miscellaneousness, or manifoldness

רבי~Rabbi = "my Master"- a tittle given to one of the highest level of Jewish religious teachers
רבי-אבא~Rabbi Abba
רבי-אבא-בר-איבו~Rabbi Abba Bar Aivo or Abba Arika (175–247)- AKA Rav- a Jewish Talmudist who lived in Babylonia, known as an amora (commentator on the Oral Law) of the 3rd century who established at Sura the systematic study of the rabbinic traditions, which, using the Mishnah as text, led to the compilation of the Talmud
רבי-אבין~Rabbi Abbin

רבי-יהודה-נשיאה-השני~Rabbi Judah (III, or) Nesi'ah II- held the office of Nasi of the ancient Jewish Sanhedrin between 290 and 320 CE. He is a famous Jewish sage mentioned in the classical works of Judaism's oral law, who lived during the third and beginning of the fourth century CE.

רבי-יוסף-בן-אפרים-קארו~Rabbi Joseph ben Ephraim Karo (Toledo, 1488 – Safed, 1575)- was author of the last great codification of Jewish law, the Shulchan Aruch, which is still authoritative for all Jews pertaining to their respective communities- to this end he is often referred to as ha-Mechaber (Hebrew = "The Author") and as Maran (Aramaic = "Our Master")

רבי-יצחק-לוריא~Rabbi Isaac Luria- aka "The Ari", "Ari-Hakadosh", or "Arizal," meaning "The Lion,"- was a foremost rabbi and Jewish mystic in the community of Safed in the Galilee region of Ottoman Palestine (He is considered the father of contemporary Kabbalah, and the interpretation of his teachings in Kabbalah is known as Lurianic Kabbalah)

רבי-ישראל-בן-אליעזר~Rabbi Yisroel (Israel) ben Eliezer- The Baal Shem Tov
רבי-ישראל-דב-אודסר~Rabbi Yisroel Dov Ber Odesser (1888 – 23 October 1994)- was a Breslover Hasid and rabbi who claimed to have received a "Letter From Heaven" sent directly to him by Rebbe Nachman of Breslov, who had died 112 years earlier, revealing to him a new remedy for relieving the world's suffering and illness (This remedy is the song and name Na Nach Nachma Nachman Meuman, which he revealed in his old age to newfound followers throughout Israel)
רבי-ישראל-סרוג~Rabbi Israel Sarug (also "Saruk") (16th century; fl. 1590–1610)- a pupil of Isaac Luria who devoted himself at the death of his master to the propagation of the latter's kabbalistic system for which he gained many adherents in various parts of Italy

רבן-גמליאל~Rabban Gamaliel
רבן-גמליאל-ברבי~Gamaliel III or Rabban Gamaliel beRabbi[Son of the Rabbi] also known by "RebbI"- was the son of Rabbi Judah haNasi (Judah I), who appointed him his successor as nasi (prince)
רבן-גמליאל-דיבנה~Rabban Gamaliel II- was the first person to lead the Sanhedrin as Nasi after the fall of the second temple, which occurred in 70 CE
רבן-גמליאל-הזקן~Rabben Gamaliel the Elder- or Gamaliel I- was a leading authority in the Sanhedrin in the mid first century- He was the grandson of the great Jewish teacher Hillel the Elder, and died twenty years before the destruction of the second temple in Jerusalem
רבן-גמליאל-החמישי~Rabban Gamaliel V held the office of Nasi of the ancient Jewish Sanhedrin between 365 and 385 CE. He was the son and successor of the Jewish patriarch Hillel II
רבן-גמליאל-הרביעי~Gamaliel IV (probably late 3rd Century CE)- was and father of Judah III. Gamaliel was the president of the Sanhedrin between 270 and 290 CE
רבן-גמליאל-השישי~Rabben Gamaliel VI (ca. 370 – ca. 425) was the last nasi of the ancient Sanhedrin
רבן-יוחנן-בן-זכאי~Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai- an important leader durring the time of the great revolt and the dustruction of the Second Temple and he was very influential in the design of modern rebinical Judaism
רבן-שמעון-בן-גמליאל~Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel (I)- first generation Tanna
רבן-שמעון-בן-גמליאל-הזקן~Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel I- was a first generation Tannaist sage and leader of the Jewish people- and succeeded his father Gamliel I as the Nasi of the Sanhedrin after his father's death in 50 CE and just before the destruction of the Second Temple
רבן-שמעון-בר-יוחאי~(Aramaic)- Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai, AKA. Rashbi- was a famous rabbi who lived in the era of the Tannaim (scholars of the Mishnah) after the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE. and is attributed by many with the authorship of the Zohar ("The Brightness")
רבנו~our teacher
רבנו-הקדוש~Revinu-Hakadosha = "Our Holy Teacher"- the title given to Rabbi Yehudah- son of Rabban Shim'on
רבנו-יונה~Rabbenu Yonah- tittle given to Yonah Gerondi (died 1263)- also known as Yonah of Gerona- a Catalan rabbi and moralist, cousin of Nahmanides
רבנו-תם~Rabbeinu Tam (c. 1100–c. 1171)- born Jacob ben Meir- was one of the most renowned French Tosafists and a foremost halachic authority of his generation. Known as "Rabbeinu" (our teacher), he acquired the Hebrew suffix "Tam" meaning straightforward; it was originally used in the Book of Genesis to describe his biblical namesake, Jacob

שבתאות~Sabbateans (Sabbatians)- is a complex general term that refers to a variety of followers of, disciples and believers in Sabbatai Zevi (1626 - 1676), a Jewish rabbi who was proclaimed to be the Jewish Messiah in 1665 by Nathan of Gaza, and vast numbers of Jews in the Jewish diaspora accepted his claims, even after he became a Jewish apostate with his conversion to Islam in 1666.

שבתי-צבי~Sabbatai Zevi (August 1, 1626 – c. September 17, 1676 in Dulcigno (present day Ulcinj), Montenegro)- was a Sephardic Rabbi and kabbalist who claimed to be the long-awaited Jewish Messiah and was the founder of the Jewish Sabbatean movement- he was forced by the Ottoman Sultan Mehmed IV to convert to Islam at the age of forty- some of his followers also converted to Islam, about 300 families who were known as the D?nmeh (aka D?nme) (converts)

שלוש-רגלים~(The) Three Pilgrimage Festivals, known as the Sh'losha Regalim- are three major festivals in Judaism — Pesach (Passover), Shavuot (Weeks), and Sukkot (Tents or Booths) — when the Israelites living in ancient Israel and Judea would make a pilgrimage to Jerusalem, as commanded by the Torah

שמעון-בן-גמליאל~Shimon ben Gamliel (I)- first generation Tanna
שמעון-בן-הלל~Shimon ben Hillel- was the son of Hillel the Elder, and when Hillel died, Shimon took over his place as Nasi. It is assumed that Shimon did not live long after this, and was quickly succeeded by his son, Gamaliel I
שמעון-בן-יוחאי~(Rabbi) Shimon bar Yochai, AKA. Rashbi- was a famous rabbi who lived in the era of the Tannaim (scholars of the Mishnah) after the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE. and is attributed by many with the authorship of the Zohar ("The Brightness")
שמעון-בן-כוסבא~Simon ben Kosiba- the original name of Simon bar Kokhba- the Jewish leader of what is known as the Bar Kokhba revolt against the Roman Empire in 132 AD
שמעון-בר-יוחאי~Shimon bar Yochai, AKA. Rashbi- was a famous rabbi who lived in the era of the Tannaim (scholars of the Mishnah) after the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE. and is attributed by many with the authorship of the Zohar ("The Brightness")
שמעון-בר-יוחי~(Rabbi) Shimon bar Yochai, AKA. Rashbi- was a famous rabbi who lived in the era of the Tannaim (scholars of the Mishnah) after the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE. and is attributed by many with the authorship of the Zohar ("The Brightness")
שמעון-בר-יונה~Simon bar Jonah- or Peter the Apostale
שמעון-בר-כוזיבא‎~Simon bar Kozeba = "Son of lies" or "Son of deception"- a referance- by rabbinical writers to Simon ben Kosiba (better knowen as Shimon bar Kokhba) after the failure of the revolt in wich he was the commander and was acclaimed as a Messiah who would restore Israel
שמעון-בר-כוכבא~Shimon bar Kokhba = "Son of a Star"- was the Jewish leader of what is known as the Bar Kokhba revolt against the Roman Empire in 132 AD, establishing an independent Jewish state of Israel which he ruled for three years as Nasi ("Ruler")- his state was conquered by the Romans in 135 following a two-year war
שמעון-הקוסם~Simon the Sorcerer- or Simon Magus- was a Samaritan proto-Gnostic and traditional founder of the Simonians in the first century AD, and is also mentioned in a great number of gnostic texts and was according to them one of the leaders of the early gnostics
שמעון-מגוס~Simon Magus- also known as Simon the Sorcerer- and Simon of Gitta- was a Samaritan proto-Gnostic and traditional founder of the Simonians in the first century AD, and is also mentioned in a great number of gnostic texts and was according to them one of the leaders of the early gnostics
שמעי~Shimei or Shimhi or Shimi or Shimea = "renowned"- a Benjamite- son of Gera of the house of Saul in the time of David, also a Benjamite- son of Elah and commissariat officer in the time of Solomon, also the Ramathite in charge of the vineyards of David, also son of Gershon and grandson of Levi, also a Levite- son of Jeduthun and chief of the 10th division of singers in the time of David, also a Levite of the sons of Heman who took part in the purification of the temple in the time of king Hezekiah of Judah, also a Levite- brother of Cononiah in charge of receiving the tithes and offerings in the reign of king Hezekiah of Judah, also a Levite who had a foreign wife in the time of Ezra, also a Judaite- son of Pedaiah and brother of Zerubbabel, also a Simeonite- son of Zacchur, also a Reubenite- son of Gog and father of Micah, also one of the sons of Hashum who had a foreign wife in the time of Ezra, also one of the sons of Bani who had a foreign wife in the time of Ezra, also a Benjamite- son of Kish and father of Jair and grandfather of Mordecai in the time of Esther, also a Levite- son of Jahath and grandson of Gershon and great grandson of Levi, also Benjamite- father of Adaiah, Beraiah, and Shimrath (spelled 'Shimhi)
שמעיה~Shemayah- or Shemaiah = "heard by Jehovah"- a prophet of the Lord in the reign of king Rehoboam of Judah, also the Nehelamite- a false prophet in the time of the prophet Jeremiah, also father of Delaiah- one of the princes of Judah in the time of the prophet Jeremiah, also an inhabitant of Kirjathjearim and father of Urijah- a prophet of the Lord in the time of the prophet Jeremiah, also a Judaite- son of Shechaniah, father of Hattush, and descendant of Zerubbabel, also a Simeonite- father of Shimri, also a Reubenite- son of Joel and father of Gog, also a Merarite Levite- son of Hasshub in the time of Nehemiah, also a Levite- son of Galal and father of Obadiah, also a Levite and head of the family of the sons of Elizaphan who were commissioned to bring the ark to Jerusalem in the time of David, also a Levite and scribe- son of Nethaneel in the time of David, also a Levite- 1st son of Obed-Edom in the time of David, also a Levite- descendant of Jeduthun the singer in the time of king Hezekiah of Judah, also a Levite- one of the messengers of Ezra to Iddo, also a Levite in the time of king Jehoshaphat of Judah, also a Levite- one of several in charge of distributing the free will offerings brought to God to their Levite brethren in the time of king Hezekiah of Judah, also a Levite in the time of king Josiah of Judah, also head of a family of exiles who returned with Ezra, also a priest, of the sons of Harim who had a foreign wife in the time of Ezra, also an Israelite of the sons of Harim who had a foreign wife in the time of Ezra, also son of Delaiah, grandson of Mehetabeel, and a false prophet hired by Tobiah and Sanballat to give false guidance to Nehemiah, also a priest who sealed the covenant with Nehemiah and participated in the dedication of the wall, also a priest who returned from exile with Zerubbabel, also a leader of the people at the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem in the time of Nehemiah, also grandfather of the priest Zechariah who participated in the dedication of the wall in the time of Nehemiah, also another of the priests who along with 25 took part in the dedication of the wall in the time of Nehemiah

﻿'אדמו"ר-הזקן'~(abbr.)- The Alter Rebbe = "Old Rebbe" (in yiddish)- Rabbi Shneur Zalman of Liadi- the founder and first Rebbe of Chabad- a branch of Hasidic Judaism
﻿'או~(abbr.)- "it is said"
